setup.question: Of the following situations, what was the toughest for Evelyn to handle?
answers: Having to dance for her boss

Text.text: im a proud feminist but im going to be honest shooting someone is prob harder
is an agent who was stationed on
, a large
built by Earth to fight off
. However, the Scythians are slowly gaining the upper hand and
them

.

As the defender is about to be captured, the leaders of the defender
in order to carry out her mission of infiltrating and destroying the Scythian ship once the defender got captured. In order to do this, she has a
; however, she is unable to find the key as
and

She decides to continue with her mission and disguises herself using
, slowly making her way to the office of
, who is the commander of this region and gets a "job" under him.
she has been dancing for Perat. The difficulty, however, is that Perat is a telepath, and as Evelyn dances Perat continuously tries to investigate her mind (out of quotes):

.

Evelyn has to concentrate on trying to block out the probe while still dancing, as if Perat finds out that she is really a spy whose mission is to destroy the Scythian ship she is sure to be killed.

Can I have more evidence surrounding Perat as a telepath? I cant quite gurantee that probe = telepath. 
Also can you cite me ev from 4907-4960?
Also does she shoot a prisoner? Give me ev from where she shoots prisoner and how she feels.
Perat being a telepath:
, she's even worried about trying to keep deceiving him:
This is what's happening between 4907 and 4960:

(that's all the quote space I have). Basically, she's trying to get more and more informationa about the Scythian area that she's found herself in while still trying to keep up appearances with Perat, which, given his telepathic skills is an incredibly difficult task.

(i'm out of quotes but i can quote all this later) The prisoner is mentioned, as this is the test that Evelyn must pass to "get the job" in Perat's office, that is, she must kill a prisoner whom Perat was going to execute in order to get the job. Though she is hesitant, she does this as it is necessary for her mission.

What is her ultimate goal after the key is destroyed? You say she continues on her mission? what is this mission without the key? Why is Evelyn so determined to complete the mission?

Also can you give me some ev for why Evelyn finds the dancing part hard? Right now I believe you she is constantly under supervision but it does really seem to suggest that the experience is super tough?
Her ultimate goal is still to destroy the Scythians. The key was given to her before she was put in her cell as a tool that would do that (323-339)

.

However, now that the key is destroyed she needs to set the movers in motion herself:

That's the reason she invades the Viscount's command, in order to get more information to carry out her mission.

The evidence is from my previous quote (3515-3540) as she herself says it would be difficult to evade his mental probing for long. It's even described as powerful:

Okay a bit difficult to for me to believe that Evelyn felt that the dance/probe was that difficult. She is also a telepath herself. I need to see how it compares with her experience with shooting the prisoner. 
 
You can just quote me ev from shooting the prisoner.
Perat tells her to kill the prisoner to get the job:
She thinks for a while:
She kills him:

It looks like there is a lot more effort put into just describing what Evelyn felt killing the prisoner. She is clearly hesitant.

 I'll give you another chance to convince me otherwise. There does not seem to be a lot of ev for the dancing/probing part. You can just cite ev about the dancing/probing, I am just going off of how much detail the author put into describing killing the prisoner vs. the bland and quick description of the 30 days of dancing.

It's not the "bland description of the 30 days of dancing" but how much effort the author goes in to describing the whole idea of Perat being a telepath, then Evelyn finding out about this, and still needing to get into his office for her mission and then having to avoid this for 30 days.

The killing of the prisoner isn't described as being tough and if you're going off pure semantics then it would, in fact, be less difficult as the author spends more time literally describing the actual death of the prisoner than Evelyn's hesitance or ""difficulty"" in killing him.

not really buying it. True it didnt get described explicitly as tough but neither was having to dance. I think the author spending time to describe the death is usually trying to set up how it is a emotional scene and a difficult time for the main character, making the toughest moment of their life more vivid/last longer.

answers.reason for outcome: I didn't have enough ev to convince the judge.
Didn't provide a lot of evidence for A. Did not have strong arguments to refute my suspicions. I did not buy the evidence debater had for A and did not buy the arguments they made against B.
